This solution allows easy integration with Tesseract, enabling text extraction from images for Document AI applications within WasmEdge. Wasi-OCR utilizes a Host Function in the WasmEdge C++ SDK, along with a Rust library crate for inputting images and extracting useful text information from the OCR engine. Tesseract, developed by Google, is an open-source OCR engine widely used for extracting text from images. It's a key component for Document AI, automating document processing tasks through machine learning and natural language processing. The file structure of Wasi-OCR includes the plugin functions, necessary modules, and the Tesseract API, which is created and destroyed during the `image_to_data` function call. To install Wasi-OCR, the Tesseract API requires the installation of two dependencies: `tesseract-ocr` and `libleptonica-dev`, which are linked via CMakeLists. When building WasmEdge with the plugin, use the `-DWASMEDGE_PLUGIN_WASI_OCR=On` flag along with the standard build process. Further build details can be found at the official WasmEdge documentation.`?

prompt: Can you assign labels to the GitHub issue titled `bug: when encounter `misaligned pointers`, WasmEdge should trap` created by `luxinyi0105`, stating `WasmEdge is not compliant with the witx spec when running a specific test case. The test case involves mutating a wasm file that was generated from a C program using Emscripten compiler. The specific mutation operation changes a subtraction of the stack pointer into a division, leading to corruption of the wasm module's in-memory shadow-stack pointer and causing the stack to be misaligned. Despite the witx spec stating that misaligned pointers should trigger a trap, WasmEdge is not returning a trap and instead outputs a checksum result without any abnormal behavior. Key Technical Details: - Test case involves mutating a wasm file obtained from a C program using Emscripten compiler - Specific mutation operation changes a subtraction into a division - This corruption causes misalignment of the stack, which violates the witx spec - Expected behavior: WasmEdge should return a trap, as per the witx spec Environment: - Hardware Architecture: x86_64 - Operating system: Ubuntu 22.04 - Tools Version: wasmedge 0.13.2 Proposed Solution: - WasmEdge needs to return a trap when encountering misaligned pointers, as specified in the witx spec.`?

prompt: Can you assign labels to the GitHub issue titled `AOT feature support iOS/android make Wasm as universal binary` created by `soplwang`, stating `We're facing the challenge of managing multiple platform and architecture configurations for Deno, Node.js, and React Native native modules, which is overwhelming. We believe that using Wasm (with AOT) could be a universal distribution solution, but WasmEdge currently doesn't support it on iOS and Android. The problem is that iOS and Android disable writable and executable memory for security reasons, which conflicts with WasmEdge's AOT loader implementation. Our proposal is for WasmEdge to perform AOT compilation of Wasm bytecodes to native static libs and default static link to WasmEdge's WASI runtime. This would address the issues we're facing with platform and architecture configurations.`?

prompt: Can you assign labels to the GitHub issue titled `WASM buffer allocation on heap section of the memory instances` created by `q82419`, stating `To enable WASM functions to access buffers, developers currently have to allocate buffers in host languages before compiling into WASM files. This poses a challenge when WASM functions require buffer pointers. The runtime API needs to provide buffer allocation support for such functions, or developers have to implement the allocation function themselves. Two approaches are proposed for WASM heap memory allocation API: 1. Using the exported `malloc` or `__new` functions of the WASM module, planned for the `0.13.0` release. 2. Maintaining the heap section on memory instances with the `__heap_base` global, with the release date yet to be determined. Relevant links: - Detect `malloc` and `__new` when loading: [WAMR #3626](https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-micro-runtime/blob/main/core/iwasm/interpreter/wasm_loader.c#L3626) - Maintain the `__heap_base`: [WAMR #202](https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-micro-runtime/blob/main/core/iwasm/interpreter/wasm_runtime.c#L202) - Allocate memory when executing: [WAMR #2498](https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasm-micro-runtime/blob/main/core/iwasm/interpreter/wasm_runtime.c#L2498) Issue reference: #2420`?

prompt: Can you assign labels to the GitHub issue titled `[WASI-NN] Problems of implementing the Tensorflow backend` created by `gusye1234`, stating `I aim to integrate Tensorflow with our WASI-NN backend. However, we faced several issues: 1. Using the C api of TF to perform a forward computation requires providing the string name of the input/output node, while we use numeric index in WASI-NN for `set_input`/`get_output`. 2. Post TF2.6, models are exported to SavedModel, containing default and user-defined signatures, requiring the passing of an exported path for loading in TF. 3. Loading SavedModel in TF necessitates passing a string path, which must be pre-opened in the WASI environment. To address these, we suggest: 1. Converting the Tensorflow model to TensorflowLite model. 2. Implementing a buffer-loading version of TF backend to handle the simple case, alongside a path-loading version for the corresponding scenario. 3. Utilizing modified WASI-NN APIs to support user indexing their inputs/outputs by string name. Further technical details and proposed solutions can be found in our GitHub repository and corresponding issues.`?

With the upcoming function-reference and GC proposal, the `ValType` type specifier may need to occupy multiple bytes for typed reference. To address this, we propose replacing the current ValType enum class with a structured class, initially functioning as a wrapper for the enum class. This structured class could accommodate additional information in the future to support function-reference and GC proposal. It's essential to consider the compatibility of the binding interface, especially for java and rust SDKs where ValType is exposed. This compatibility may need reevaluation considering the proposed changes.`?

prompt: Can you assign labels to the GitHub issue titled `[Internal] New file manager pattern` created by `dannypsnl`, stating `The top-level form of WASM is traditionally the module, but in the component model, it's not. To address this, the new implementation needs machinery to stop the loader from reading all the data via an infinite loop.  One proposed solution is to create a file manager with a range, each manager for a specific purpose. This will also remove `loadContent` callback issues. For example, we can now write code like this: ```cpp auto SecSize = FMgr.loadU32(); loadSection(Comp->getAliasSection(), FMgr.subRange(*SecSize)); ``` To achieve this, it's important to extract `FMgr` from `Loader` to avoid falling back on a class-based approach. Additionally, consideration should be given to moving out `loadXxx` member functions to address the issue of a god class `Loader`. Those member functions often don't share any state.`?

A host function can call `yield` to save the VM state and pass execution to the host, and then use `resume` to resume VM execution. The required APIs are: ```c void* WasmEdge_ResultPending(WasmEdge_VMContext*, WasmEdge_Result) void* WasmEdge_Yield(void* Data) WasmEdge_Result WasmEdge_VMResume(void* Data) void WasmEdge_VMInitFromFile(WasmEdge_VMContext*, char*) WasmEdge_Result WasmEdge_VMRun(WasmEdge_VMContext*, WasmEdge_String, WasmEdge_Value[], WasmEdge_Value[]) ``` An example use case involves defining a `HostFn` function, and an `main` function initializing the virtual machine. The code demonstrates registering a host function, instantiating a WebAssembly module, running a function, pending VM execution, and then resuming from the pending state. The proposed action includes integrating the provided example use case with the required APIs to enable `yield` and `resume` operations for host functions. The main technical challenge here is understanding and correctly implementing the `yield` and `resume` operations to manage VM state effectively.`?

Second, there's a concern with the use of Emscripten's SDK to produce WebAssembly binaries with custom headers and sections, which can result in unexpected behavior.  The proposed solution involves providing a method to set the content type for the HTTP response when dynamically loading WebAssembly, and considering the use of custom section names and headers when dealing with WebAssembly binaries generated using Emscripten's SDK. The main challenges lie in addressing these issues to ensure consistent and predictable behavior when working with WebAssembly modules. The author has requested assistance with implementing a solution for specifying the content type of HTTP responses, along with advice on working with Emscripten's SDK to avoid unexpected behavior caused by custom headers and sections in WebAssembly binaries.`?

The primary challenge lies in ensuring consistent operand types for the vector shift operator.`?

To address this, I propose copying the data to the host functions to prevent potential issues with model data ownership. This approach aims to mitigate the risk of segment faults caused by freeing the model data prematurely. The discussion for this can be found in the provided pull request (https://github.com/WasmEdge/WasmEdge/pull/2360). For further reference, the TfLite model format with metadata is available at: https://www.tensorflow.org/lite/models/convert/metadata#model_with_metadata_format.`?

prompt: Can you assign labels to the GitHub issue titled `[WASI-NN] tensorflow lite backend - fix set_input and get_output bugs when checking` created by `yanghaku`, stating `Update errno for wasi-nn plugin [(wasi-nn spec main branch)](https://github.com/WebAssembly/wasi-nn/blob/main/wasi-nn.wit.md). The ```TfLiteTensorCopyToBuffer``` function requires that ```output_data_size``` matches ```TfLiteTensorByteSize(tensor)```. When ```OutBuffMaxSize``` is less than ```TfLiteTensorByteSize(tensor)```, TfLite will return ```kTfLiteError``` and wasi-nn plugin will return ```Success```. In this case, the wasi-nn plugin may return ```InvalidArgument``` to indicate a failure in ```get_output```. Additionally, in the ```SetInput``` function, the variable ```DimensionBuf``` is used before checking if it is ```NULL```, and the variable ```TFDimension``` is unused and thus candidates for removal. To mitigate these issues, dimension and tensor byte checks have been added to ensure ```input_data_size``` matches ```TfLiteTensorByteSize(tensor)```. In relation to the tflite API, it is essential for the WASI-NN TensorFlow Lite plugin to ensure that the ```model_data``` is not released or modified during the lifetime of the ```TfLiteModel``` and any ```TfLiteInterpreter``` objects created from it, to prevent a segment fault. The next steps entail resolving the outlined issues.`?

C++ enum classes `WasmEdge::ValTypeCode`, `WasmEdge::RefTypeCode`, and `WasmEdge::NumTypeCode` provide codes. `WasmEdge_ValType` is the struct for storing value type data, and `WasmEdge_ValTypeCode`, `WasmEdge_RefTypeCode`, and `WasmEdge_NumTypeCode` are C enums for the codes. prompt: Can you assign labels to the GitHub issue titled `Shipping binary precompiled WASM files is problematic for downstreams` created by `paravoid`, stating `As a Debian Developer, I'm interested in packaging WasmEdge for Debian inclusion. However, the current WasmEdge tarball includes WASM binaries, which doesn't align with Debian's strict inclusion rules. While I can repackage the tarball to remove these binaries, I'd prefer to explore alternative solutions before resorting to that. The good news is that the shipped WASM files may not be necessary for a default release build. Here's a breakdown of the categories of shipped WASM files and potential solutions: 1. Handcrafted WAT files can possibly be dropped and regenerated by the build system when necessary, or accepted as binaries alongside their sources. 2. Rust sources shipped in tree can be rebuilt in Debian, but removing the precompiled .wasm from the tarball might be the safest option for inclusion. 3. C sources shipped in tree can also be removed from the tarball, as they seem to be there as references and are not relied upon at build time. 4. Rust and C sources published online are not included in the tarball, posing a blocker for Debian inclusion. Rebuilding them using the specified toolchains and including their sources might make them acceptable for inclusion, while the more complicated cases may require removal from the tarball, with URLs or CMake files to fetch them from their respective repositories for source installations. Ultimately, addressing these issues may benefit not only Debian but also other distributions with similar rules. I'm keen on collaborating to find a suitable solution for Debian's inclusion needs while aligning with upstream requirements.`?

prompt: Can you assign labels to the GitHub issue titled `[Compiler] lld on macho requires -arch and -platform_version to always be specified` created by `hydai`, stating `Reference: https://reviews.llvm.org/D97799 I want to propose a change in the behavior of the LLVM optimization passes. Currently, the `mem2reg` optimization pass misses an opportunity to eliminate redundant lifetime markers in some cases. This leads to redundant lifetime markers being emitted, which negatively impacts the optimization effectiveness.  To address this, I propose adding a new optimization to merge redundant lifetime intrinsics when running `mem2reg`. This optimization would improve the overall performance and maintain the correctness of the LLVM IR. I specifically request feedback on whether this change aligns with the LLVM optimization goals and would appreciate any insights on potential challenges or alternative approaches.`?
